title: 115_s1909
content: The Act may be cited as the "Beneficiary Enrollment Notification and Eligibility Simplification Act of 2017" or the "BENES Act of 2017". It pertains to eligibility and enrollment notification. The "Beneficiary Enrollment Notification and Eligibility Simplification Act of 2017" or the "BENES Act of 2017" focuses on eligibility and enrollment notification for Medicare individuals, particularly those over 60 years of age. The Act amends Section 1804 of the Social Security Act to include new notification requirements for potentially eligible individuals. The "BENES Act of 2017" targets Medicare eligibility and enrollment notification for individuals over 60 years of age, as well as individuals with disabilities, end-stage renal disease, low-income families, employers, states, health insurers, agents, brokers, and other groups specified by the Secretary. The BENES Act of 2017 focuses on Medicare eligibility and enrollment notification for various groups specified by the Secretary. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to consultations made under this Act. The notice required must include information on eligibility for benefits, late enrollment penalties, and coordination of benefits. The BENES Act of 2017 addresses the coordination of benefits under Medicare Part B, including scenarios involving primary and secondary coverage, retiree health coverage, group health plans, coverage under the Affordable Care Act, and other available options for eligible Medicare individuals. The BENES Act of 2017 ensures that potentially eligible Medicare individuals receive timely notices about their enrollment options. Notices must be sent at least two times, either with the individual's Social Security statement or separately if the individual does not receive a statement. The BENES Act of 2017 mandates timely notices for potential Medicare enrollees, including a centralized enrollment webpage with online tools and information coordinated by the Secretary. Interagency coordination is required within two months. Interagency coordination involving the Secretary, Secretary of the Treasury, and Commissioner of the Social Security Administration is required to identify potentially eligible individuals for notifications. The Secretary must review and update notices annually for Medicare enrollment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can request disclosure of return information from the IRS to determine eligibility for certain programs for potentially eligible Medicare individuals. The Department of Health and Human Services and the Social Security Administration can access taxpayer information to determine eligibility for Medicare. This information includes taxpayer identity, filing status, and other details specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Department of Health and Human Services and the Social Security Administration can access taxpayer information for Medicare eligibility purposes. The disclosed information can only be used by authorized personnel for this specific purpose. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Commissioner of Social Security will enter into a computer matching agreement to implement sections of the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code. A report on the implementation process must be submitted to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of this Act. The report will include the status of notices created under a specific section, and an evaluation of their impact on enrollment in the Social Security Act. It will be publicly available. SEC. 3. BENEFICIARY MEDICARE PART B ENROLLMENT PERIODS AND EFFECTIVE DATE OF COVERAGE. Beneficiary Medicare Part B enrollment periods and effective date of coverage are amended under Section 1838(a) of the Social Security Act. The amendment specifies effective dates based on enrollment criteria, with different scenarios outlined for individuals enrolling before or after January 2019. The effective dates for Medicare Part B enrollment are determined based on specific criteria outlined in Section 1838(a) of the Social Security Act. Different scenarios are provided for individuals enrolling before or after January 2019, with specific dates specified for enrollment. The effective dates for Medicare Part B enrollment are determined based on specific criteria outlined in Section 1838(a) of the Social Security Act. Different scenarios are provided for individuals enrolling before or after January 2019, with specific dates specified for enrollment, such as the first day of the month following enrollment. The enrollment periods for Medicare Part B are outlined in Section 1837(e) of the Social Security Act. There is a general enrollment period from January 1 to March 31 before 2019, and specific enrollment criteria for 2019 and subsequent years. The general enrollment period for Medicare Part B is from October 15 to December 31 of the previous year, with special enrollment periods for individuals meeting exceptional circumstances. Section 1839(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to change the wording regarding the enrollment period to the close of the month.
